summary: This is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, dated August 8, 2019, which designates executors for his estate and directs that his entire estate be transferred to The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust. It outlines extensive powers granted to the executors for managing the estate. This is the Last Will and Testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, executed on January 18, 2019. It details the disposition of his estate, including provisions for taxes, a trust agreement, and the appointment of executors and trustees. The document includes standard legal clauses and is signed by Epstein and witnessed.

connections.description: Epstein appointed Indyke as an executor of his will, granting him fiduciary authority over the estate.
Epstein appointed Kahn as an executor of his will, granting him fiduciary authority over the estate.
Epstein designated Ruemmler as a successor executor to take over if the primary executors cannot serve.
Both are appointed as co-executors of Epstein's estate, required to act unanimously on certain decisions.

locations: St. Thomas, United States Virgin Islands
New York (State and County mentioned in affidavit)
Palm Beach, Florida (Location where notarization occurred)
keyFacts: Jeffrey E. Epstein's entire estate, after specific payments, is bequeathed to the trustees of 'The Jeffrey E. Epstein 2019 Trust' created on January 18, 2019.
Epstein appointed Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn as the primary executors of his will, with Kathryn H. Ruemmler named as the successor executor.
Each executor is to receive a fixed compensation of $250,000 upon completion of the estate's probate, with no other compensation for serving.
The will grants the executors extremely broad powers to manage, invest, sell, and litigate on behalf of the estate without needing judicial approval for most actions.
The document includes a 'no-contest' clause, stating that any beneficiary who challenges the will or trust forfeits their interest.
Jeffrey Epstein executed his Last Will and Testament on January 18, 2019, approximately seven months before his death.
The will references a separate 'Trust Agreement' and directs the disposition of his estate through both the will and that trust.
It contains detailed provisions for the payment of federal and state transfer taxes from his probate estate and 'Apportionment Assets'.
The document includes a 'no contest' clause (in terrorem clause) designed to disinherit any beneficiary who challenges the will.
The will was notarized in Palm Beach, Florida, by Notary Public Amanda Devine.
